Definition: A programming interface for web documents that represents the structure of the document as a tree of objects.
To join two or more strings end to end in programming.
The process of creating an instance of an object from a class in object-oriented programming.
The automatic conversion of one data type to another, such as converting a string to a number in JavaScript.
The deliberate conversion of one data type to another, such as using Number() or String() in JavaScript.
A JavaScript value representing an unrepresentable or invalid number.
To assign an initial value to a variable.
A data structure that stores a collection of items, usually of the same type, in an ordered list.
"consists of a start tag, its attributes (if any), content, and an end tag. It is a fundamental building block of a web page."
An HTML structure wrapped in angle brackets, such as <div> or <span>.
Defines the layout of a grid-based structure in CSS.
A CSS layout model for creating flexible and responsive design.
A property in CSS used to set the border around elements.
A semantic HTML tag that represents a section in a document.
A semantic HTML tag used to represent a list of commands or menu items.
The 'defer' attribute is a boolean attribute for the <script> tag that makes the browser wait to execute the script until the HTML document has been fully parsed.
An object in JavaScript that represents a single moment in time and allows you to get or set various date and time components.
A function associated with an object, accessed using dot notation, such as dateObject.getFullYear().
An inline element in HTML used to apply styles or scripts to a small portion of text or content.
Allows JavaScript to be executed after the document has been parsed, improving performance and avoiding blocking rendering.
A property of the document object that returns the date and time the document was last modified.
Objects are data structures, while methods are functions associated with those objects. Methods are accessed using dot notation, like object.method().
The root object representing the entire HTML document in the browser. It provides methods and properties for interacting with the document.
String literals in JavaScript that allow for embedded expressions, using backticks (`) and ${} for variable interpolation.
A control flow statement used to execute one block of code among many options based on the value of a variable or expression.
Statements like if, else if, and else that allow for conditional execution of code segments based on whether a condition is true or false.
Statements like for, while, and do...while that allow for repetitive execution of code segments as long as a condition remains true.
A method that returns the first element within the document that matches the specified selector, or group of selectors.
An event triggered when an element is clicked, often used to trigger specific functions in response to user interaction.
An event triggered when a key is released after being pressed. Useful for handling input changes in real-time.
An event that fires when the initial HTML document has been completely loaded and parsed, without waiting for stylesheets, images, and subframes to finish loading.
A security mechanism for browser-based applications. It allows for safe execution of potentially untrusted code, without risking the security of the rest of the site.
"<link rel="stylesheet" href="#">"
<script src="#" defer></script>
"Header, NavBar, Main, Footer - if applicable sidebar, Hero Section"
HTML element that is used to represent self-contained content, such as illustrations, diagrams, photos, code snippets, or other content that can be referenced as a single unit

"To apply styles using the :hover pseudo-class, you directly attach it to the element selector without spaces. For example, to change the background color and text color of a link with the class .menu-tags on hover, you use the syntax .menu-tags:hover { background-color: #b0c4b1; color: black; }. Incorrect usage, such as including a space between the element and the :hover, will prevent the styles from being applied correctly."

"commonly achieved using the text-align property. This property can be applied to a parent container to align its child elements' text content. To center text, use text-align: center; on the parent element containing the text."
"For vertical centering within a container, additional properties like display: flex;, align-items: center;, and justify-content: center; on the container may be needed."
"border: width style color;"
"border-radius: 5px;"

"The console.log() method is a built-in function in JavaScript used to print output to the browser’s console. It is commonly used for debugging purposes, allowing developers to log messages, variable values, or any other information to help track the flow of execution or identify issues in the code.
Example:

const name = 'Alice';
console.log('Hello, ' + name); // Outputs: Hello, Alice
In this example, the console.log() method prints the message Hello, Alice to the console. It is an essential tool for troubleshooting and understanding code behavior during development."

"The first parameter is the type of the event (like click or mousedown or any other HTML DOM Event.)

The second parameter is the function we want to call when the event occurs.

The third parameter is a boolean value specifying whether to use event bubbling or event capturing. This parameter is optional.

Note that you don't use the 'on' prefix for the event; use 'click instead of onclick"
A method that attaches an event handler to an element without overwriting existing event handlers. It allows an element to respond to multiple events.
A method that returns the first element within the document that matches the specified CSS selector(s). If no matches are found, it returns null.
